From: Peter Williams <pezra@...>
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=304236879; y=BPfLUe00wgoz8YtXRogypVp4yk88BFcYRktgecYwFpVlLaD5sfDDKnZ_rw
X-Yahoo-Profile: peter_e_williams

On Mon, Jan 9, 2012 at 6:09 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
> g=
ood to see your reply.

I am very happy to have this conversation. I am hav=
ing very similar
conversations at work, and i am trying to decide exactly w=
hat i think.

> - omitting _properties_ of the message? not following you h=
ere. maybe an example you
> can point to would clear this up for me.

Well,=
 if a human goes to a web page in a browser we just omit any
links they are=
 not allowed to execute (either because they are not
authorized, or because=
 the state of the resource does not allow it). I
was suggesting that we mig=
ht do the same thing with any other media
type.

> - seems you assume M2M h=
ere in several of your replies. is it your POV that
> RDF is only to be use=
d in M2M scenarios? or do you mean to say that some of
> the affordances is=
 describe have no value in M2M cases?

I did not mean to imply that RDF wou=
ld *only* be useful in the M2M
scenario. I do think RDF is more compelling =
for M2M use cases, though.
We already have a quite good media type for use =
cases that involve
real time user interaction (HTML). No need to reinvent t=
o wheel for
those use cases. For automata use cases HTML is somewhat less
c=
ompelling.

As for affordances, I am not sure i see the same set of afforda=
nces
you do, or at least not in the same way. By analogy, in the physical
w=
orld some affordances are possible because of the laws of nature or
the evo=
lution of the human body, other are based purely on cultural
convention (eg=
, up usually maps to forward). I think the "embed" link
affordance is based=
 on a set of cultural conventions (img usually maps
to embed). However, whi=
ch culture a client belongs to depends on what
it is trying to accomplish a=
nd what technology it uses. So different
clients might interprete the same =
feature as a different affordance.

> - IME, transclusion is not exclusivel=
y a H2M (human-to-machine) affordance, i use
> "x:include" quite often in M=
2M cases

I agree that automated user agent can make good use of transclusi=
on.
However, i am inclined to think that the decision of whether to
transcl=
ude belongs to the client rather than the server. Proxies to
not transclude=
 any representations in html, regardless of the flavor
of those links. Scre=
en readers have no need to transclude images in
HTML. Nor do (most) automat=
ed user agents, for that matter.

Are these clients wrong/broken when they =
choose to treat a "embed"
link as a "navigation" link?

Under what circumst=
ances would it be wrong/broken for an automated
client to transclude a "nav=
igation" link if it could successfully
interpret the resulting document?

>=
 - templates (URI or body) are of mixed value in M2M, IME. as long as the v=
ocab is
> stable and the templates are used to control timing and flow, thi=
s has worked well
> for me. of course H2M templates are much easier to supp=
ort since the selector is
> not in the code, but in the head of the human.
=

Agreed. There are situations where templates provide significant
value. (E=
g, give me a list of thing created between two timestamps.)
However, that v=
alue is less overwhelming in M2M scenarios.

> finally:
> <snip>
>> So is y=
our point that no one has bothered to put together a decent RDF
>> based me=
dia type? =A0Or that it would be very difficult/impossible to do
>> so?
> <=
/snip>
>
> is it possible? not sure. my first attempts have not been good, =
but that's proly *me*<g>.

That is not promising. Though as you point out, =
not conclusive.

> is it *important*? not really. CSV doesn't provide affor=
dances and it does
> quite well. my comment here is really about my particu=
lar experience.

Well, CSV does quite well as a data format. But not so wel=
l as a media
type on which to build complex distributed applications.

> i =
am writing apps where clients are expected to recognize, parse,
> and (in s=
ome cases) render and/or activate affordances in responses.
> When i implem=
ent those apps, RDF is not something i find fits the bill;
> that's all.

F=
air enough. The rendering part does seem like it would be a bit
harder to h=
andle with RDF. All the UI logic would have to be directly
coded into the c=
lient(s).

Peter
barelyenough.org
